newsitem.title: CHINA: Drought in north China; Yangtze floods predicted.
newsitem.headline: Drought in north China; Yangtze floods predicted.

text.p: About 2.167 million hectares of land under winter wheat in northern China is suffering from drought as of April 22, the Xinhua news agency said on Saturday.

There has been virtually no rainfall over most of northern China since mid-April and temperatures have been slightly higher than usual, Xinhua said, quoting the State Anti-Flood and Drought Headquarters.
China reaped a bumper grain harvest of 490 million tonnes in 1996, surpassing the previous year's record 466 million tonnes, official figures show.
Last year's record harvest was achieved despite a five-month drought in northern and central China and floods in southern rice-growing regions.
In southern China, severe flooding is likely along the Yangtze River this year, Xinhua said, quoting experts of the Yangtze River Water Resources Commission.
The upper reaches of the river would be more prone to floods in the months ahead, Xinhua said. It did not give a reason.
Local governments along the river have intensified efforts to improve their flood control facilities, it said.
